commentBody: I liked CUETIPS next to QSCORE.

A very fun puzzle.  I look forward to more puzzles from Howard Neuthaler!  

(I liked the 'cuetips' and 'qscore', also.)
The plural SATINS does not strike me as unusual. I know it from the Porgy and Bess lyric, ‚ÄúI‚Äôll dress you in silks and satins.‚Äù
Woo doggy. That was a pretty tricky little Tuesday. a total blast. Well done, Howard Neuthaler.

Wow, nice puzzle.  Kind of difficult for this early in the week, no?  A theme and everything.

I wasn't expecting this much of a challenge, although the solving was fairly smooth and quick in the end....

This was a bright Tuesday.  I really liked BLOODTYPO and NOTQUITO (perhaps because I managed to guess both before I had any crosses, which I seldom manage with theme answers).

Seeing the Queen of country torch singers, Patsy CLINE, sent me to Spotify to to play a few tear jerkers.
This puzzle's URL should be https://www.nytimes.com/2024/09/16/crosswords/daily-puzzle-2024-09-17.html (i.e., 9-17, not 9-15). It's the puzzle for Tuesday, September 17.
INUK crossing DEKE was a stumper for me, but otherwise a fun, challenging, but not too difficult Tuesday! I LOL‚Äôd at all the punnies.
Looks like there‚Äôs a typo on this page for the answer to 24D - doesn‚Äôt the puzzle (and his actual name) only have one T?

Entirely positive experience, clever theme, vivid cluing.  Over the years I've learned a lot about eels from the clues here. This week I learned that no-one knows much about their erotic or procreative life, and today I learned that they are nocturnal. That gives them all day to fool around somewhere private, away from those eelers (whose erotic life also remains somewhat of a mystery). There's a bar not far from where I live called Nooners. It attracts a certain clientele and repels everybody else.  A place like that is where I would look for eels on the make, if I were an eelologist. Eels probably look for that spark of electricity between them, or maybe I'm projecting. I read somewhere that Freud in his student days dissected hundreds of eels in a search for their male sex organs. That doesn't seem to rank high on a list of his achievements, but we did learn from him that the Naughty and Nice are the same people; the nice people suppress their naughty side & are the unhappier for it; and vice versa -- the trick is to be naughty AND nice, isn't that Freud 101? Asking for an eel. 

Back to this fine debut.  I like the northerly vibe of ICE WINE (which is, yes, TOO SWEET for the likes of me -- plus one for that cross!), the INUK, the NHL'ers deking away -- our Mario Lemieux was perhaps the finest deker I've ever seen, he could deke the tennis shoes off an eel. SAME HERO's cluing was inspired, and to finish off with LEMON LIMO, awesome, 10 out of 10. Voila!

Next month will be four years since I seriously committed to solving the crossword every day. My average times have stabilized over time, which is to be expected. A very slow or very fast time has less effect, the larger the data set. 

What surprises me though is how often my daily time is within a few seconds, high or low, of my average. This has to be a testament to the edtiors' skill at slotting a puzzle into the correct day and tweaking and tuning the clues for that day.

From here, it looks like a challenging job done extremely well.

Congratulations on and thank you for a sparkling debut, Mr. Neuthaler!

I think my synapses are firing rather slowly, as I got hung up in a few spots. Either that or this was, in fact, a crunchier Tuesday than usual.

It didn't help that I've never heard "Presto CHANGO" and have always known it to be just "Presto!" Then again, I don't watch magic shows, so that would explain it. And yet, I did catch on to the trick and thought it was quite clever.

Thank you for a fun romp!

My friend always complains when his jalopy breaks down. He's a lemon harangue guy.

(I think he wrote "The Fault in Our Cars.")

O WELLGEE that was neato (a little crosswordpuzzlese).   The fills had a sort of giddy quality, which made it especially delightful.  NOTQUITO was inspired, as were soooo many others. TOOKPAINS gave me the BLOODTYPO (knew it couldn't be some kind of toe thing) and the fun was in looking for more.  I don't play a lot of hockey and stalled on DEKE, felt like a yoyo, and finally had to look for it. 

Howard Neuthaler, it's hard to believe that 39 of your puzzles were a no go.  Thank you for persevering!  More to follow, I hope!

Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Mr. Neuthaler! I particularly liked SAME HERO. 

Your perseverance is inspiring. 

I hope we‚Äôll see you back here soon.
good first go. A few tortured clues.

Ok, it appears my long post did not make it past the automated moderation. The thing is, I have no idea why that would happen. I wrote of nothing objectionable at all. I wish there were a warning when trying to post something that it might be rejected.

Loved this puzzle!  Thank you for a fun time.  Congratulations on your successful debut today Mt. Neuthaler. I can't wait to see your next one!  I knew I was in for a good time right away when I saw your clever clue for 17A.  It was my favorite. Perfection. 23A was so very clever as was 41A. Even you crosses were great. Thank you NYT crossword team for providing such quality crosswords. 

  I'm not a big football fan, but have been instructed to give a shout out  to my alma mater UT for being #1and emphasize the high degree of talent that it takes to play for the LONGHORNS. So here it is HEEHAW, GO HORNS, you rock. Cheer from Texas y'all.

This was a fun solve with a clever theme.
An excellent Tuesday romp!

I've had ICEWINE a few times.... very expensive for a small bottle, and definitely a dessert wine. Imagine if you condensed regular wine by a third... very intense and sweet flavor.

Hopefully today's column will have fewer unhappy posters than yesterday (though much of that thread has been emued).

üòä

What a clever theme! NOT QUITO and LEMON LIMO are brilliant.

The inclusion of several other long-O words like SLOMO, ALPO, OPPO, CAMEO, AGO and UM NO is molto BUONO. 

I often overindulge on that dessert drink made from frozen grapes.  Just call me an ice wino.  

Congratulations, Howard, on your NYT debut. With 39 rejections I'd say it was longo-verdue!
Really enjoyed the puzzle, but I don't get the Lemon Limo clue, maybe because I'm not from the states? Can someone clue me in what it has to do with breaking down?

I was thrown off by the word "surprising" in the Ecuador one - who decides what people know and what they don't? It's not uncommon for a capital not to be the most populous city in its country (is it, Americans?). I live in northern Peru though, fairly close to Ecuador's most populous city, so yeah maybe less surprising than for most.

Juicy puzzle this. Like the lemon limo (crossed with Go Long!) I encountered some difficulties along the way. Some clues really stretched me. Incidentally, I make a drink that I call Chango. It‚Äôs water kefir flavoured with mango and cherry. Well, I like it anyway. No me la quito.

I enjoyed it. A bit harder yhan Tuesday usually 
is, but (just?) enough to make it interesting.
Terrific debut, Howard. I loved the theme, especially NOT QUITO.  Looking forward to your next one!

Fun puzzle. A bit on the slow side for me, but tumbling to the trick was the big turning point and that's always a nice touch. Big smile when each of the theme answers finally dawned on me. 

Kind of on the edge of dad jokes, so definitely right up my alley (oops).

VERY unusual puzzle find today. I'll put that one in a reply. 

..

I seem to be finding quite a few of the puzzles harder than the day they appear, and today was no exception.  
Nothing wrong with the puzzle,  very clever theme and lots of interesting entries and I‚Äôm certainly impressed with Howard‚Äôs efforts.  Hopefully the next one won‚Äôt take as long to be accepted.

Great puzzle! Very clever theme. Absolutely loved it. But how in the world is this a Tuesday? This is Thursday material, Wednesday at worst. This is too tricky for the average Tuesday solver. Not understanding a lot of Fagliano‚Äôs editorial decisions. 

Speaking of, Saturday‚Äôs puzzle had a MASSIVE no-no slip through the cracks. SANTA was used in both a clue and an answer. How in the world was that missed? Unless, he‚Äôs changing the rules of crossword construction?

Good morning Sam, 

There is a "Typo" in your 24D explanation. You added an extra T in Elliot. 

Or did you do that in purpose? ;)

Loved the theme questions, but have to assume that Presto Chango is an American term, as it is not familiar to me at all. Give the couple of Americanised cross clues, I was stuck on C..NGO til the very end.

Tired today‚Äîhad to get up in the middle of the night to catch a 6 am flight to Miami. Or rather, to sit on the pre-dawn runway for an hour waiting to take off. That may be why it took me quite so long to get the theme. I had a rebus in there until the last (of many) minutes. Sigh. 

But, once I figured it out, aha! Satisfying and pretty funny. Thanks for a pleasant diversion, Howard Neuthaler & eds.

Mmm‚Ä¶
Crunchy!

Love a Tuesday that actually feels like
meal and not a snack!

And not for nuthin‚Äô but 
fantastic debut, 

that had a slew of Os
and not an

Eno
Ono, or
Oreo in sight!!

Way to gO!

CheeriO!
Six minutes longer than usual, and a few lookups too. Harder than the average Tuesday!

My brain wasn't at it's best today as I did a long flight yesterday but waking up and doing this crossword was exactly what I needed. A fun theme that I could really get behind and simple but fun cluing makes this one of my favorite Tuesdays. Definitely a crossword I'll look back at. Good job Howard!

Very original and funny, and for me a smooth solve. 

I'm glad to see INUK instead of Inuit, given all the debate that's gone on in this space on the topic (i.e. the misuse of INUIT as a singular noun). 

ICEWINE is a Qu√©bec specialty, and I've tried it a few times -- nice flavour, but high-priced. A somewhat better value, if you like apples, is cidre de glace.  Now (or in a few weeks for the peak fall coulours) is the time to come to southern Qu√©bec and go on a winery (or cidrerie) tour!
Very nicely done Mr. Neuthaler. A devilishly tricky Tuesday and a very fun solve. Great way to get the neurons firing along with a good cup of coffee and a lap kitty üò∫.
I'm glad Mr. Neuthaler persevered, because submission #40 was a winner! A really fun theme that was well-executed. I especially appreciated BLOODTYPO as the first theme entry.

Well, holy moly, this debut puzzle was submitted after 39 rejections. Long before that, so many would have BAILed, or at least stopped sending puzzles to the Times.  Started doubting their ability.  But no, Howard persisted, and, as I imagine him, tried to do better, tried to learn from what feedback he got.  Kept at it.

And oh, the day he got a yes!  The flood of feelings.  The excitement.

This is not a going-through-the-motions puzzle, as one might expect after 39 rejections.  The theme has spark, with each theme answer a riddle in its own right, so I was motivated throughout, taking stabs and feeling quite satisfied when I figured one out with few crosses.  The theme clues/answers brought me smiles. Lovely answers deepened the solving pleasure ‚Äì GO LONG, TOOK PAINS, CUE TIPS, CULT FILMS.

This is not just another grid ‚Äì it has a bold look without scattershot black squares, and it has never appeared before in the Times.  At 72 words and 34 blocks it is more Thursday/Friday than Tuesday, yet still works because the theme, cluing, and answer set are Tuesday.

Howard, I am inspired by your persistence, your continuing to tell yourself, ‚ÄúOkay, I‚Äôll find another way,‚Äù until you reached success.  You, sir, are my hero of the day!

Another terrific Toughened Up Tuesday with a clever theme. 
Thanks to all.
************************
************************

‚ÄúWithhold my skepticism‚Äù (as mentioned by our columnist regarding magic) was for me a good motto today. I felt the initial rabbit ears sticking out of the hat (BRB, EEL, ADO) were eventually offset by some interesting, if not quite magical, clues and/or answers (SAMEHERO, LEMONLIMO, [Prominent part of a bowline knot], and for hungry me, GORGES which can tend toward onomatopoeia if you eat just right=wrong).

And in Mini news, start making plans now for your Dec 5, 2024 celebrations of World Soil Day.

1. Read the clue that listed [. . . B poditive. . .] 

2. Thought, "Wait until I get to the comments to blast the editors!" 

3. Dutifully filled in BLOODTYPe

4. Got caught up short on TOeKPAINS

5.  Slapped forehead. 

That I can be so slow witted in the morning constantly amazes me.    That it took 39 Steps to get to this gem of a debut is also amazing (Would love to see some of those, bet they are great too).  Many thanks.

Definitely harder than the average Tuesday, unlike yesterday‚Äôs, which I breezed through though my comment was eaten by the emus. Who knows why, I think it‚Äôs personal. They hate me. 
Haven‚Äôt come across PRESTO CHANGO before. When would it be used? Is it the equivalent of abracadabra?

An excellent Tuesday puzzle constructed by a college classmate! Encountered in the wild! And a reminder to make my next platelet donation appointment (O poditive if you‚Äôre wondering)! What a morning.
I got the jingle at the end while thinking one-third of my entries were wrong.
Re: Satins‚Äî By itself it may not be common, but ‚Äúsilks and satins‚Äù is a not uncommon phrase.
An awesome debut, Mr. Neuthaler.  All I can say is, today's puzzle is the Home of the Bravo!

My 1500th overall solve, but current streak if far, far, below that by more than 1400. Sometimes work, other commitments, and the occasional particularly frustrating puzzle gets in the way of long strings of daily solves. Today‚Äôs grid was a Tuesday-plus difficulty for me, but I found it clever and enjoyable.

Mr. Neuthaler writes of 40 tries before the NYT finally accepts this puzzle. He then goes on to tell us the lovely story of the crew which supports/solves his puzzle making efforts. The puzzle was a  nice Tuesday but the story was the real gift. Thank you sir.
In the column, it should be ELLIOT (with only 1 T), as it is in crossword (and as is the actor's name).

Very fun, but it felt a bit stiff for a Tuesday. Things like QSCORE and TOOKPAINS felt a little shoehorned, but the theme was full of zingers. BLOODTYPO was a great opener, and SAMEHERO got a genuine guffaw out of me.

I always enjoy a grid that goes easy on the three-letter fill, and this one served up plenty of great, meaty 4/5/6-letter answers.

Well worth the slight difficulty bump for a fun theme and excellent wordplay!

Okay, Herr Neuthaler...  I was doing quite well filling in this puzzle (even though I wanted it spelt CHANGE-O) and then I hit the NE corner.  
GOLLY GEE, what did I ever do to *you*???
OH EM GEE, I keep switching between ONEISH and TWOISH, and neither of them is helping.
I can't CURE the animal hides, or DRY them or DYE them.
Assigned DESK? SPOT? 
Barrel DREGS?  DROSS?  WASTE?
16A def seems unfair...

And then I stumbled upon LISTS (duh!!)
WELL GEE....  Pretzel RODS?  Srsly??
And NOT QUITO doesn't work because most of us know how to correctly pronounce QUITO....

No soup for you!  One year!
Typo in the companion, it is Elliot Page not Elliott page like you put in all caps...

Maybe the most enjoyable Tuesday puzzle I've ever done.  The themers are all so imaginative and so funny.  It takes a certain kind of wacky wit to come up with these and I can picture Howard chortling with delight as answers like BLOOD TYPO, SAME HERO, and LEMON LIMO came flooding into his brain.  They are all quite delicious and they're all clued in an exceptionally playful way.

But Howard also TOOK PAINS with the non-themer clues.  He seems to have been having fun there as well, as he clued MOI and BARBELLS and COLBERT and GO LONG.

Sometimes a constructor's personality shines through and makes you feel that this is someone you'd enjoy having lunch with.  This is one of those times.  A delightful puzzle.

Strands #198
‚ÄúOn the rebound‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üîµüü°

Clever! 



As always, please don't include any spoilers until there are at least three replies / posts are behind the View All Replies button. 






I'm on the rebound after a series of Strands that just didn't click with me... 
How about you, emus?

A nice Tuesday entry, although the northeast gave me fits for a while.  Sticking with it, I chipped away and ultimately heard the happy music.  The theme fills were well played, if not slightly obvious.

Howard, I admire your never say die attitude.  One must always expect editorial rejection when submitting for publication, but continuing after 39 rejections is truly admirable on your part.  I have felt somewhat demoralized after a few rejections of my Metropolitan Diary submissions, but I continue with the hope that my next one will be published.

Ok seeing mostly complementary responses so going to be brutally honest, I thought this puzzle was terrible and not up to snuff. 

I love a theme, this one misses the mark. "Change O" to me should imply we should be changing all Os in the theme answers or changing letters to O's. This theme is neither. Every answer in the theme is literally what the fill should be. The theme answers should of been "blood type", "same here", "not quite", and "lemon lime", we as the solvers then could of felt the magic by "change O" the last O to reveal fill that fits. As the theme is now all of the fill is literally what it should be and I guess it's loosely put together that if you change the last O it's a still word. Weak. How is this a "brilliant illusion"? 

Not feeling the magic in this one.

I almost broke down and looked up stuff around the revealer. I have never heard the expression "Presto CHANGO" or the term ICE WINE, and NHLERS were a mystery (or rather, the names of the clubs were - I knew we were dealing with sports teams, but of which sport?), much like the name of local American politicians. In the end though with crosses (I did know ELLIOT) and some plausible guesses I managed to deal with that area on my own, but damn, it certainly was not Tuesday difficulty for me. Had I not known Page's name, I would have needed lookups - on a Tuesday! I am personally still not a fan of trivia-heavy puzzles, especially ones with naticky crosses.

Also, having read the column, as I understand it the revealer is pronounced [change-oh]? How do you get that from the spelling? I can only see it rhyming with mango. Or am I misunderstanding the revealer and it is simply about there being an O where you would expect an E in CHANGO, much like in the themed answers? 

I partially understood the theme, and it sort of helped me complete the grid - in Wednesday time.
Dude, it's a Tuesday puzzle.  That NE corner was ridiculous for the day.
Was I the only person who input LEMONSINE before the revealer? LEMONSINE hive rise up
Good theme. Time just above my Tuesday average, which means I had to think - a good thing. Loved LEMONLIMO! Congrats on the debut.

All's right in Wordplay now.

Sam fixed a typo
and an emu ate
a (related) thread.






SRSLY!
Excellent puzzle, if a bit difficult for a Tuesday, and congrats on your acceptance after so many rejections! Your perseverance is admirable. Keep it up!
Did anyone else try mosquito?

Naticked on a Tuesday! 

EHUD/DEKES tripped me up - I clearly need to brush up on my hockey lingo and my knowledge of former world prime ministers. 

This one was fun! I didn't even notice the TYPOs in my quick first reading of 17A, and I enjoyed the "aha!" when I came back to it.
Really found this one difficult for a Tuesday. Not on the setter's wavelength at all and perhaps a bit out of my knowledge of some of the American cultural references. A few nice clues though

I love a challenge and a chuckle. Today's puzzle took me about 50% longer than the average Tuesday, but made up for it with the delightfully absurd fill on the long entries. Thanks for the good cheer, Howard Neuthaler, and I hope to see more of your work soon.

Interesting spread of comments. I did think it was a bit harder than the usual Tuesday‚Äîit took me a few passes to get there. I do agree with the NE corner gripes, because if you don‚Äôt know Enola either spot or slot fits as a cross, so you don‚Äôt even realize you have to run the alphabet there. I had Enopa for a long time, I mean, who knows, it could be anything. I really liked the ‚Äúbloodtypo‚Äù and expected the rest of the theme to follow that, but they just ended in O, so I didn‚Äôt get that there were any changes. Did i miss something there? 
But in general it was good, some clever clues. On to Wednesday.
Scot crossing Clyde was nice too. Great puzzle.

Yikes, that was a toughiO for MOI! Good fun but tough! 

I actually had to do a lookup... on a Tuesday! And maybe I didn't have to but I chose to because I don't think I could have completed the section where the revealer is in the left middle without it. I was already way long for a Tuesday.

For the life of me, I could not think of a Hollywood star whose last name was Page. I wasn't tricked by the veiled capital, I just didn't know who it was. And everything else there was a no go for me. I eventually remembered the DALEYs but that was it. I couldn't think of anything that would follow presto, even though I had all the theme set completed and I knew the revealer must end in O. 

I don't know if it was that much tougher or if I'm that much slower today but it was fun nonetheless. I really liked each of the themed answers - very fun! And I'm proud that I've been remembering DEKES as a hockey trick. Now if only I could remember NHL team names. What I know about hockey, could fill a hockey stadium! Or is it arena? Ugh, see!?

O well!  Hi ho, hi ho, back to workO, I go!
A very clever theme! Thanks for the smiles.

Wow!

What a pleasantly surprising fun and challenging puzzle for a Tuesday!

I mean, not difficult. Just a little higher bar than a typical Tuesday. 

Nice!

My interest was piqued by Sam‚Äôs mention of the Penn and Teller card trick ‚Äúon roughly 1000 guests at a gala over Zoom. I have barely managed to pull my jaw off the floor since‚Äù. I‚Äôm a bit surprised she didn‚Äôt link that one. Anyone know to what she was referring?

‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî

‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî
At first, I thought wow an actual typo in the New York Times! But no‚Ä¶.A fun and tricky Tuesday. Thank you.

"B poditive"?
For a moment there, I thought we were heading into the sci-fi territory of the pod people.

But it was a cleverer theme than that.
Thanks, Mr. Neuthaler. More puzzles, please.
Wonderfully clever theme. I was so happy to have remembered DEKES from other puzzles. üòä

Sorry, the revealer didn't do it for me. I realize "presto chango" is a thing but I don't like just chango.



hangconstructor used PRESTOCHANGO instead.

The constructor notes on this puzzle points out something that I think about a lot.

And that is almost no one (or maybe even no one at all) makes any kind of a living based on these puzzles.

This was Mr. Neuthaler's 40th attempt!   I defy almost anyone to point out a similar level of passion and drive.  And in the end he may have ended up with $500.  

And this is why I reflexively defend constructors from attacks here.  I realize not all puzzles are as ingenious as others, but anything that appears has spent a lot time in gestation.

And it hurts me to think that after all that...after all that...they get responses like "Terrible puzzle".

It just rubs me the wrong way.  If these were multi-millionaire athletes getting booed, it would be one thing.  Crossword puzzle makers are not in the same league in compensation, and, I my oh so very humble opinion, should also not be in that league when it comes to criticism.

Here's a question to ponder...

Suppose we had all the clues, and the clue told us how many letters were in the answer.  But there's no crossing, just the clue and the number of letters in the answer.

How many would we get right?

One percent?  Two?

My method of solving seems quite different, in that I look for short answer gimmes, because I'm more likely to come up with a short one than a long one.  

Once I have those letters, I try to branch out from there, again starting with the shorter ones.  

So most of the answers I enter are only entered after at least one letter has shown up in a reasonably solid cross.

I almost never answer a long one without at least a few letters.
Typo on clue 33D -- the comma should come after the inverted commas!

Congrats on the debut, Howard! 
My favourites today : BARBELLS, EMERGE, MOI.

Doable puzzle, but ‚Ä¶ someone (or a recognised dictionary) from the UK might sometimes be useful in the checking process.  There is no name for ‚Äúperson from Edinburgh‚Äù that‚Äôs common enough to be in a British one-volume dictionary.  Glaswegian was enough on its own, but Aberdonian would have been an addition that made more sense.  (-burgher in particular makes little sense, as in speech, Edinburgh doesn‚Äôt end with the same sound as Hamburg or Pittsburgh.)
What a fun theme! BLOODTYPO made me laugh when I figured it out and then the rest of the themed words clicked :)
Seems odd to explain BARBELLS in the tricky clues and not DEKES. (I watch a fair amount of hockey maybe the commentators have said it and I didn‚Äôt register)
@C-64 Yes! I came to say the very same. CUETIPS was giving us a cue for QSCORE.

@Alan Young
Agreed, Alan. Sam, no problem with cottons, linens, woolens, silks or satins. Although if satins really were a bit of a stretch - they‚Äôd be jerseys.

@Marshall Walthew

It says it right on the box:  Do not put anything into your ear!

Of course, everyone uses them to clean between the keys of their computer keyboard...

Not!

@Steve L 

"Don't put anything smaller than your elbow into your ear."

The most difficult rule I've ever encountered.  I'm a rule follower, but that one is one I just have to ignore.

They itch!!!

What am I supposed to do about that?

I wonder if somewhere along our evolutionary lines there were humans with fingers so small they could easily get into their ears, but the characteristic died out because so many of them became deaf, and couldn't woo or be wooed.

@john ezra -- First paragraph, why you are such a gift to us, and perhaps to all mankind.  Magnifique!








Et tu, emu.
@john ezra So awesome, I‚Äôm still r(eel)ing from and f(eeling) the r(eely) great laughs!! Thank you for st(eel)ing the Comments show!

@Cat Lady Margaret -- And when this person handed you a resignation, you would say, "NO PROBLEMO!"








Et tu, emu.
@Mike The fault in our cars?! I had to comment here just to say I really laughed out loud.

@Andrzej 

We're all right there with you.

Chances are high you were just unlucky.  

We've asked for more exposition on how moderation works, but what we got was a "quiz" to help us understand what gets past and what doesn't.

I don't know anyone that it helped.

@Francis 

Exactly.  Which "quiz" was itself massively internally inconsistent.

It's the way of the E.M.U. and they've made very clear they have no intention of turning off the filter that was apparently made using 1981 era information theory and content analysis.

On the "bright" side this means it's less likely Andrzej's post was rejected by an actual human.....
@Andrzej   Reading of rain in Poland, I thought of you and hope you are safe and dry.

@S√∏ren Thustrup 
In light of your comment about ALPO, I think it is relevant to point out that the last time this entry appeared was just recently on 8/14/2024. It was clued as  [Purina rival] and the first person to point out the fact that Purina owns ALPO was Caitr√≠ona Shanahan, who claimed to be from Kerry, Ireland. I guess at least one international solver was all over that clue‚Ä¶.

 ‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî

‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî  ‚Äî

@Eric Hougland "Clyde the Glide" flourished in the early 90s in Portland (losing in the finals to the Pistons and Bulls) and then Houston (winning in 1995). He was a member of the 1992 Dream Team but clearly overshadowed by at least eight of his teammates.
@Hann In the US, a "lemon" can also be a dreadful car (a rust-bucket old banger).

The T word reminded me of our recent quest to find homeowners insurance. (It turns out that a lot of carriers are not writing new policies in Colorado because of wildfire risk.) The questionnaire from our carrier included ‚ÄúT_____: Yes/No.‚Äù My husband thought ‚ÄúT_____‚Äù was some sort of insurance code. @Michael 

A few hockey-related comments:  

First of all, I‚Äôm not a big NHL or hockey fan, so I couldn‚Äôt confirm or deny how common it is to distinguish NHL players from other hockey players (NHLER), but I‚Äôll say that it doesn‚Äôt seem to be much of a thing with sports that I do follow (MLBer, NLer, ALer, NFLer, etc.)

On the other hand, it‚Äôs odd that DEKES is always considered a ‚Äúhockey term‚Äù.  I never thought that to be exclusively the case. Just last night, the Mets‚Äô second baseman (or maybe shortstop) deked a runner going to second that he caught the ball thrown to him, so the runner didn‚Äôt get up and advance to third. The announcer flat out said something like ‚ÄúAlvarez deked him and he holds at second.‚Äù  I‚Äôve heard it used in football, too, and though I‚Äôm not a big hoops fan, I‚Äôm pretty sure they say it in basketball, too. The word, by the way, is just a shortening of decoy. 

And finally: today‚Äôs NHLER clue would have been much better if they‚Äôd used the **Jets** and the Sharks.

@HeathieJ 

It's a strange phenomenon having an answer right on the tip of your tongue but can't dig it out of our brains.

What does it mean that "we can't find the answer"?  What are our brains doing when they try to recall something that is there and yet isn't quite?

I suspect one of the last areas human will understand, if we don't slip on an apocalyptic banana peel, will be our own brains.  Maybe the most mysterious three pounds of goo anywhere in the universe, although I suspect there are thousands of advanced civilizations out there.  I also suspect that not even one of them has managed to contact another.

Wonderful Tuesday.  Inventive,  but not difficult. I was trying to put "cue sticks" in but "cue tips" is even better.  I pictured trying to clean your ears with a pool cue.

The ALPO/CLYDE crossing was impossible for non-U.S. solvers. Or very hard, at least.

The Ecuador/brand crossing was also impossible for me. Other than that, great puzzle!

I almost did a lookup when I realized that ‚Äúdregs‚Äù was not the answer to 9A [Bottom of the barrel]. Then I finally thought of LISTS for 21A (why didn‚Äôt I think of that sooner?

I was a little annoyed at 42D - QSCORE. This seems like some kind of marketing jargon you would only know if you‚Äôre in the industry. I had never heard of it. I also needed all the crossings for 28A. But ‚Ä¶ I solved it without lookups! And  I love this theme, especially BLOODTYPO and LEMONLIMO. So clever! Four minutes over my average but my Tuesday streak of 14 Tuesdays in a row is still alive! (Though my 30-Mondays-in-a-row streak ended yesterday. üòî)

Love these write ups but just one point of feedback. NHLer is a pretty popular term in ice hockey that hockey fans hear regularly. It's user to distinguish between professional players in other leagues ("lower" leagues and international) and those playing in the NHL.

@Hann 

To add to Hardroch‚Äôs explanation, most US states have ‚Äúlemon laws,‚Äù which are designed to protect a person who buys a new car that repeatedly has mechanical or electrical problems.

@John Carson

One British lady was very, very VERY fond of saying, "Hey, Presto!" every time she completed a step.  She must have said it dozens of times in the half-hour show....  I cannot hear or see that now without an awful moment of flashback.
